{{Infobox referendum | name = Nationwide referendum proposal 3 | title = 你是否同意依下列原則制定「政黨不當取得財產處理條例」，將中國國民黨黨產還給全民：國民黨及其附隨組織的財產，除黨費、政治獻金及競選補助金外，均推定為不當取得的財產，應還給人民。已處分者，應償還價額。
(See below for translation) | location = [[Taiwan]] | date = 12 January 2008 | yes = 3891170 | no = 363494 | total = 4550881 | electorate = 17277720 }} {{Infobox referendum | name = Nationwide referendum proposal 4 | title = 您是否同意制定法律追究國家領導人及其部屬，因故意或重大過失之措施，造成國家嚴重損害之責任，並由立法院設立調查委員會調查，政府各部門應全力配合，不得抗拒，以維全民利益，並懲處違法失職人員，追償不當所得？
(See below for translation) | location = [[Taiwan]] | date = 12 January 2008 | yes = 2304136 | no = 1656890 | total = 4505927 | electorate = 17277720 }}{{Politics of the Republic of China}} Two referendums were held in [[Taiwan]] on 12 January 2008, alongside [[Taiwan legislative election, 2008|legislative elections]]. One (officially numbered as Question 3) concerned [[transitional justice]] and the treatment of contentious properties acquired by the [[Kuomintang]],[http://news.bbc.co.uk/chinese/trad/hi/newsid_7160000/newsid_7165000/7165026.stm 台選舉公投爭議落幕將采一階段投票] BBC News, 30 December 2007 {{zh icon}} whilst a counter-referendum (Question 4) was initiated by the Kuomintang on alleged corruption in politics.[http://news.bbc.co.uk/chinese/trad/hi/newsid_7160000/newsid_7166000/7166028.stm 國民黨抵制追討黨產公投] BBC News, 31 December 2007 {{zh icon}} The referendum was considered to be a dress rehearsal for a [[Taiwanese United Nations membership referendums, 2008|more contentious referendum]] on support for Taiwan admission to the United Nations to be held in March.{{citation needed|date=March 2008}} Although a majority of voters voted in favour of both proposals, voter turnout was only 26%, well below the 50% required to make the results valid. The legislative elections had a turnout of around 58%. ==Questions== ===Proposal 3=== This question was officially championed by former premier [[Yu Shyi-kun]]. {{cquote|Do you agree that the following principles should be followed to legislate a ‘Regulation for the Disposal of Properties Inappropriately Acquired by Political Parties’, in order to return such properties of the Kuomintang to the people?: Kuomintang’s and its associate organization’s properties{{spaced ndash}}outside of party dues, political donations, and public subsidies{{spaced ndash}}should be presumed inappropriately acquired and returned to the people. Those already liquidated, the party should compensate at market value. (你是否同意依下列原則制定「政黨不當取得財產處理條例」，將中國國民黨黨產還給全民：國民黨及其附隨組織的財產，除黨費、政治獻金及競選補助金外，均推定為不當取得的財產，應還給人民。已處分者，應償還價額。)}} ===Proposal 4=== This question was officially championed by former finance minister [[Wang Chien-shien]]. {{cquote|Do you agree that legislation should be enacted to investigate the responsibility of leaders of the nation and their subordinates, when there is grave damage to the nation due to their wrongful intentions or grave failure in carrying out their duties? Further, do you agree that Commissions of Inquiry should be set up by the [[Legislative Yuan]] to investigate such matters; and that the departments of the government should co-operate fully without resistance, in order that the benefits of the people will be preserved? That the personnel criminally at fault should be punished and their illegal income be recovered? (您是否同意制定法律追究國家領導人及其部屬，因故意或重大過失之措施，造成國家嚴重損害之責任，並由立法院設立調查委員會調查，政府各部門應全力配合，不得抗拒，以維全民利益，並懲處違法失職人員，追償不當所得？)}} ==Campaign== The Kuomintang urged voters to boycott both referendums to prevent them from reaching the 50% voter turnout needed to for validate the result, and there was much pre-election controversy over the format and structure of the balloting. Initially, the Kuomintang was in favor of a two-step balloting system where voters would vote for the legislative elections and then for the referendum, while the DPP was in favor of a one-step system in which voters would get all four ballots to vote. The final system was a one-step, two-table system in which voters would get the ballots at separate tables but would mark the ballot papers together. ==Results== {| class=wikitable style=text-align:right !rowspan=2|Question !colspan=2|For !colspan=2|Against !rowspan=2|Invalid/
blank !rowspan=2|Total !rowspan=2|Registered
voters !rowspan=2|Turnout !rowspan=2|Outcome |- !Votes !% !Votes !% |- |align=left|Proposal 3||3,891,170||91.46||363,494||8.54||296,217||4,550,881||rowspan=2|17,277,720||26.34||{{No2|Quorum not reached}} |- |align=left|Proposal 4||2,304,136||58.17||1,656,890||41.83||544,901||4,505,927||26.08||{{No2|Quorum not reached}} |- |align=left colspan=12|Source: [http://db.cec.gov.tw/histFile?voteCode=20080101T1A2&resourceCode=R1 CEC] |} ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.cec.gov.tw/files/20080109171842_0109%A4%A4%BF%EF%B7%7C%B3%F8%AF%C8%BDZ.jpg Ballot specimens from the Central Election Commission] * [http://www7.www.gov.tw/egov/7thvote/index.htm Official bulletin on the referendums and the legislative election] * [http://vote2008-1.nat.gov.tw/en/R0/00000000000.html Results of the two referendum questions from the Central Election Commission] * [http://www.gio.gov.tw/ct.asp?xItem=35776&ctNode=2462 Government Information Office explanation on the referendum] {{Taiwanese elections}} [[Category:2008 elections in Taiwan|Transitional justice referendum]] [[Category:2008 referendums]] [[Category:Referendums in Taiwan|2008 transitional justice]] [[Category:Transitional justice]]

[[File:Tictu owl logo foia.png|thumb|right|200px|Official logo of TICTU, scanned from documents obtained via the [[Freedom of Information Act (United States)|Freedom of Information Act]].]] The '''Telecommunications Intercept and Collection Technology Unit''' (TICTU) is part of the [[Electronic Surveillance Technology Section]] (ESTS) of the [[FBI|Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI)]]. Its primary function is performing [[surveillance]] of [[U.S. citizen]]s.
The TICTU is in charge of operating and maintaining [[DCSNet]], and performs millions of domestic [[wiretap]]s each year.
==See also== * [[Carnivore (software)]] * [[Communications Assistance For Law Enforcement Act]] * [[DCSNET]] * [[Mass Surveillance]]
==References== * [http://blog.wired.com/27bstroke6/2007/12/fbi-recorded-27.html FBI Recorded 27 Million FISA 'Sessions' in 2006] * [https://www.eff.org/files/filenode/061708CKK/082707_dcs06.pdf FOIA documents regarding TICTU] (from the website of the [[Electronic Frontier Foundation]])
{{DEFAULTSORT:Telecommunications Intercept And Collection Technology Unit}} [[Category:Surveillance]] [[Category:Mass surveillance]]

{{Redirect|The elders||The Elders}} {{EngvarB|date=September 2014}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2014}} {{Infobox non-profit |name = The Elders |image = The Elders Logo.jpg |founded_date = 18 July 2007 |founder = [[Nelson Mandela]] |location = [[London]] |key_people = [[Mary Robinson]] (Chair)
David Nussbaum (CEO) |mission = "help resolve some of the world's most intractable [[Group conflict|conflicts]]" and other issues. |num_employees = 16 (as of 2018) |num_members = 13 (including 4 Elders Emeritus) |homepage = {{URL|theelders.org}} }} '''The Elders''' is an international non-governmental organisation of [[public figure]]s noted as elder [[Politician|statesmen]], [[peace activist]]s, and [[Human rights activists|human rights advocates]], who were brought together by [[Nelson Mandela]] in 2007. They describe themselves as "independent global leaders working together for peace and human rights". The goal Mandela set for the Elders was to use their "almost 1,000 years of collective experience" to work on solutions for seemingly insurmountable problems such as [[Global warming|climate change]], [[AIDS|HIV/AIDS]], and poverty, as well as to "use their political independence to help resolve some of the world's most intractable [[Group conflict|conflicts]]".[http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/59C0C017-4A63-4F97-9D91-D1A336A2B83A.htm] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070821142020/http://english.aljazeera.net/NR/exeres/59C0C017-4A63-4F97-9D91-D1A336A2B83A.htm|date=21 August 2007}} ==History== The Elders is, as of November 2018, chaired by [[Mary Robinson]], and consists of eight Elders and five Elders Emeritus.{{Cite web|url=https://www.theelders.org/article/mary-robinson-appointed-new-chair-elders|title=Mary Robinson appointed new Chair of The Elders|website=The Elders|access-date=2018-11-02}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/about|title=About The Elders|last=|first=|date=|website=|publisher=TheElders.org|accessdate=1 November 2018}} [[Kofi Annan]] served as chair from 2013 until his death in 2018; [[Desmond Tutu]] served for six years as chair before stepping down in May 2013, and remains an Elder Emeritus.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/kofi-annan-appointed-chair-elders |title= Kofi Annan appointed Chair of The Elders |publisher=TheElders.org |date=10 May 2013 |accessdate=17 May 2013}} The group was initiated by [[Richard Branson]][http://www.scotsman.com/news/world/branson-planned-mandela-mission-to-prevent-iraq-war-1-1050218 Branson planned Mandela mission to prevent Iraq war], ''[[The Scotsman]]'', 18 December 2004 and musician and human rights activist [[Peter Gabriel]], together with anti-[[apartheid]] activist and former [[President of South Africa|South African President]] [[Nelson Mandela]]. Mandela announced the formation of the group on his eighty-ninth birthday on 18 July 2007 in [[Johannesburg]], South Africa.{{cite web| url= https://www.youtube.com/view_play_list?p=C801BC01AA46FEC2 |title= The Elders press launch in Johannesburg, South Africa |publisher=YouTube |date=18 July 2007 |accessdate=26 April 2011}} At the launch ceremony, an empty chair was left on stage for [[Aung San Suu Kyi]], the human rights activist who was a [[political prisoner]] in [[Burma]]/Myanmar at the time. Present at the launch were Kofi Annan, [[Jimmy Carter]], [[Graça Machel]], [[Nelson Mandela]], [[Mary Robinson]], [[Desmond Tutu]], [[Muhammad Yunus]], and [[Li Zhaoxing]]. Members who were not present at the launch were [[Ela Bhatt]], [[Gro Harlem Brundtland]], [[Lakhdar Brahimi]], and [[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]].{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/07/18/world/africa/18safrica.html?_r=1&scp=3&sq=%22the+elders%22+mandela+branson&st=cse|title=Former Leaders Create Freelance Global Diplomatic Team|first=Michael|last=Wines|publisher=}} [[Martti Ahtisaari]] joined The Elders in September 2009, [[Hina Jilani]] and [[Ernesto Zedillo]] in July 2013,{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/martti-ahtisaari-joins-elders|title=Martti Ahtisaari joins The Elders|website=The Elders}} and [[Ricardo Lagos]] in June 2016.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/former-president-chile-ricardo-lagos-join-elders|title=Former President of Chile Ricardo Lagos to join The Elders|website=The Elders}} In June 2017, former UN Secretary-General [[Ban Ki-moon]] also joined the group.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/former-un-secretary-general-ban-ki-moon-joins-elders|title=Former UN Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon joins The Elders|website=The Elders}} The Elders are funded by a group of donors who are named on the advisory council. == Members == === The Elders === # [[Lakhdar Brahimi]], former Foreign Minister of [[Algeria]] and United Nations envoy # [[Gro Harlem Brundtland]], former [[Prime Minister of Norway]] and former Director-General of the [[World Health Organization]] # [[Hina Jilani]], international human rights defender from [[Pakistan]] # [[Graça Machel]] (Co-Deputy Chair), former Education Minister of [[Mozambique]], President of the Foundation for Community Development, widow of [[Samora Machel]] and widow of [[Nelson Mandela]] # [[Mary Robinson]] (Chair), former [[President of Ireland|President]] of Ireland and former [[Office of the United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights|United Nations High Commissioner for Human Rights]] # [[Ernesto Zedillo]], former President of [[Mexico]] # [[Ricardo Lagos]], former [[President of Chile]] # [[Ban Ki-moon]] (Co-Deputy Chair), former [[Secretary-General of the United Nations]] === Elders Emeritus === # [[Desmond Tutu]], [[Archbishop of Cape Town|Archbishop Emeritus of Cape Town]], former Archbishop Primate of the [[Anglican Church of Southern Africa]] and former Chair of South Africa's [[Truth and Reconciliation Commission (South Africa)|Truth and Reconciliation Commission]], [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate # [[Jimmy Carter]], former [[President of the United States|President]] of the [[United States]], [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate # [[Fernando Henrique Cardoso]], former [[President of Brazil]] # [[Ela Bhatt]], founder of the [[Self-Employed Women's Association of India]] # [[Martti Ahtisaari]], former [[President of Finland]], [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureateMykkänen, Pekka: [https://www.hs.fi/politiikka/art-2000005912320.html Martti Ahtisaari luopuu arvo­valtaisen The Elders -ryhmän aktiivi­jäsenyydestä] ''Helsingin Sanomat'' 26.11.2018. === Former Elders === * [[Nelson Mandela]], a [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate and former [[President of South Africa|president]] of South Africa, was the founder of The Elders. * [[Muhammad Yunus (economist)|Muhammad Yunus]], founder of [[Grameen Bank]], [[microcredit]] pioneer and Nobel Peace Prize laureate, is a former Elder. Yunus stepped down as a member of The Elders in September 2009, stating that he was unable to do justice to his membership of the group due to the demands of his work.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/muhammad-yunus-steps-down |title= Muhammad Yunus steps down |publisher=TheElders.org |date=21 September 2009 |accessdate=26 April 2013}} * The Myanmar opposition leader and Nobel Peace Prize laureate [[Aung San Suu Kyi]] is a former honorary Elder. During her period under house arrest, the Elders kept an empty chair at each of their meetings, to mark their solidarity with Suu Kyi and Burma/Myanmar's other political prisoners. In line with the requirement that members of The Elders should not hold public office, Suu Kyi stepped down as an honorary Elder following her election to parliament on 1 April 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-congratulate-aung-san-suu-kyi |title=The Elders congratulate Aung San Suu Kyi ahead of her appearance in parliament in Burma/Myanmar |publisher=TheElders.org |date=19 April 2012 |accessdate=26 April 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130131102824/http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-congratulate-aung-san-suu-kyi |archivedate=31 January 2013 |df=dmy }} * [[Li Zhaoxing]], former [[Foreign Minister of the People's Republic of China]], attended the launch.{{cite web|url=http://www.chinese-embassy.org.za/eng/znjl/t342752.htm |title= Former Chinese Foreign Minister Li Zhaoxing attended the launching of "the Global Elders", a new think tank initiative on globe issues |publisher= Embassy of the People's Republic of China in the Republic of South Africa |date= |accessdate=26 April 2011}} * [[Kofi Annan]], former [[Secretary-General of the United Nations|Secretary-General]] of the United Nations, [[Nobel Peace Prize]] laureate === Donors and team === The work of The Elders is coordinated and supported by a small team based in London.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/about/team |title=The Elders' Team |publisher=TheElders.org |accessdate=20 August 2018}} The team is headed by David Nussbaum, who was appointed chief executive officer (CEO) in October 2016.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/david-nussbaum-appointed-chief-executive-officer-elders|title=David Nussbaum appointed Chief Executive Officer of The Elders|website=The Elders}} The Elders are independently funded by a group of donors, who also make up The Elders' Advisory Council: [[Richard Branson]] and Jean Oelwang ([[Virgin Unite]]), [[Peter Gabriel]] (The Peter Gabriel Foundation), [[Kathy Calvin|Kathy Bushkin Calvin]] (The [[United Nations Foundation]]), [[Jeremy Coller]] and Lulit Solomon (J Coller Foundation), Randy Newcomb (Humanity United), [[Jeffrey Skoll]] and Sally Osberg ([[Skoll Foundation]]), Amy Towers (The Nduna Foundation), Jeff Towers (Jeffrey Towers and Associates), and Marieke van Schaik ([[Nationale Postcode Loterij|Dutch Postcode Lottery]]). [[Princess Mabel of Orange-Nassau|Mabel van Oranje]], former CEO of The Elders, sits on the advisory council in her capacity as Advisory Committee Chair of ''Girls Not Brides''.{{cite web|url= http://theelders.org/about/donors |title= The Elders: Donors |publisher=TheElders.org |accessdate=25 April 2013}} The Elders publish annual reports detailing the organisation's income and spending activity.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/sites/default/files/the-elders-annual-report-2015-final.pdf |title=Annual report |date=2015 |website=theelders.org |format=PDF}} ==Work== The Elders carry out initiatives in two broad areas: promoting dialogue and building peace; and supporting efforts to alleviate human suffering, particularly caused by extreme poverty, injustice, or intolerance.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/initiatives|title=Our Work|publisher=TheElders.org|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100526080654/http://www.theelders.org/initiatives|archivedate=26 May 2010|df=dmy-all}} ===Current Work=== ====Universal Health Care==== At the [[Women Deliver]] conference in May 2016, The Elders launched a new initiative to campaign for [[Universal health care|Universal Health Coverage]] (UHC) as part of their efforts to support and implement the UN [[Sustainable Development Goals]] (SDGs).{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-launch-new-initiative-universal-health-coverage-women-deliver|title=The Elders launch new initiative on Universal Health Coverage at Women Deliver|website=The Elders}} The initiative focuses on four areas: 1) Promoting UHC as the best way to achieve the health Sustainable Development Goal.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/faqs-uhc-and-sustainable-development-goals|title=UHC explained: Universal Health Coverage and the Sustainable Development Goals|website=The Elders}} 2) Promoting UHC's health, economic and political benefits;{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/faqs-uhc-delivers-substantial-health-economic-and-political-benefits|title=UHC explained: Universal Health Coverage delivers substantial health, economic and political benefits|website=The Elders}} 3) Prioritising women, children and adolescents in UHC's implementation;{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/faqs-women-children-and-adolescents-uhc-priority|title=UHC explained: Women, children and adolescents as a UHC priority|website=The Elders}} 4) Reiterating the role of public financing in sustainably funding UHC.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/faqs-public-financing-key-uhc|title=UHC explained: Public financing is the key to UHC|website=The Elders}} In September 2016, Gro Harlem Brundtland delivered a keynote speech at a high-level event on the sidelines of the [https://www.un.org/en/ga/71/meetings/ 71st UN General Assembly] in New York. Joined by [[Margaret Chan]], Director-General of the [[WHO]] and health ministers of South Africa and Thailand, she called for courageous leadership to achieve Universal Health Coverage by 2030.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/accelerating-progress-toward-uhc-2030|title=Accelerating progress toward UHC by 2030|website=The Elders}} In January 2017, Kofi Annan sent letters to Indian leaders to commend the progress made in reforming the Indian healthcare system,{{cite web|url=http://www.hindustantimes.com/delhi/after-kofi-annan-former-norway-pm-praises-aap-govt-s-mohalla-clinics/story-PErXELux8KNYtyT7wLQ4uM.html|title=After Kofi Annan, another world leader praises AAP govt’s mohalla clinics|date=2 February 2017|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-urge-bold-steps-reach-universal-health-coverage-india|title=The Elders urge bold steps to reach Universal Health Coverage in India|website=The Elders}} and Gro Harlem Brundtland and Ernesto Zedillo delivered keynote speeches at the [http://www.pmaconference.mahidol.ac.th/index.php Prince Mahidol Awards Conference] in Bangkok, Thailand. Gro Harlem Brundtland highlighted the importance of inclusive health policy {{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/social-inclusion-what-does-it-mean-health-policy-and-practice|title=Social Inclusion: What Does It Mean for Health Policy and Practice?|website=The Elders}} and Ernesto Zedillo explained how to sustainably implement Universal Health Coverage.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/four-pillars-ensure-inclusive-uhc|title=Four pillars to ensure inclusive UHC|website=The Elders}} Highlighting the link between access to affordable health care and gender equality, in January 2017, two members of The Elders expressed concern at the re-introduction of the [[Mexico City Policy]] by the recently inaugurated [[President of the United States]], [[Donald J. Trump]]. The pro-abortion activist Gro Harlem Brundtland said: "This decision puts the health of women and children at risk" and warned that "vulnerable people will die unnecessarily."{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-statement-us-reintroduction-global-gag-rule|title=The Elders’ statement on US reintroduction of "Global Gag Rule"|website=The Elders}} ====Refugees and Migration==== In October 2015, Kofi Annan, Gro Brundtland and Hina Jilani joined [[UN High Commissioner for Human Rights]] [[Prince Zeid bin Ra'ad|Prince Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein]] and the Director General of the [[International Organization for Migration]] [[William L. Swing]] at an event on the refugee and migration crisis at the [[Graduate Institute]] in Geneva. During the event, Gro Harlem Brundtland said "Too many leaders are not only shy when it comes to making this case to their people, they fundamentally lack the courage to do so…". Prince Zeid Ra'ad Al Hussein also rejected the dehumanising rhetoric adopted by some politicians towards refugees and migrants.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/show-political-courage-over-refugee-crisis|title=Show political courage over the refugee crisis|website=The Elders}} Ahead of the UN Summit for Refugees and Migrants in September 2016, Kofi Annan, Maarti Ahtisaari and Lakhdar Brahimi visited Germany to launch a report calling for political will to ensure that responsibility is truly shared between countries, and for the vulnerable are protected. They met the then-Foreign Minister Frank-Walter Steinmeier, and Federal President Joachim Gauck, and also visited a refugee resettlement centre in Berlin to hear directly from new arrivals to Germany.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-hail-germanys-engagement-refugee-and-migration-issues|title=The Elders hail Germany's engagement on refugee and migration issues|website=The Elders}} The report "[http://theelders.org/article/challenge-lies-opportunity-how-world-must-respond-refugees-and-mass-migration In Challenge Lies Opportunity: How the world must respond to refugees and mass migration]" outlined four key principles which The Elders believe should be at the heart of the international response to refugees and mass migration: # Response mechanisms to large flows of people must be developed and properly coordinated, both regionally and internationally # Assistance to major refugee-hosting countries must be enhanced # Resettlement opportunities must be increased, along with additional pathways for admission # Human rights and refugee protection must be upheld and strengthened Three Elders attended the [https://www.un.org/en/development/desa/population/migration/events/ga/2016/addressrefugeesmigrantssummit.html UN Summit for Refugees and Migrants] on 19 September 2016, which was held during the 71st Session of the [[United Nations General Assembly|United Nations' General Assembly]].{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-visit-unga-high-level-week-new-york-17-22-september-2016|title=Elders’ Visit to UNGA High-Level Week, New York, 17-22 September 2016|website=The Elders}} Martti Ahtisaari, Hina Jilani and Mary Robinson spoke at the high-level Round Tables which addressed different aspects of the topic: vulnerabilities of refugees and migrants, responsibility-sharing and respect for international law, and addressing the drivers of migration, respectively. In January 2017, The Elders condemned the US [[refugee ban]], enacted by the recently inaugurated President of the United States, Donald J. Trump. Kofi Annan said: "It is deeply regrettable that a nation of immigrants should turn its back so harshly on refugees escaping violence and war.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-condemn-us-refugee-ban-call-global-protection-vulnerable|title=The Elders condemn US refugee ban, call for global protection of vulnerable|website=The Elders}} ====Stronger UN==== At the [[Munich Security Conference]] in February 2015, the Elders launched the "Stronger UN" initiative, which promoted a series of reforms to strengthen the [[United Nations]]. This included a review of the composition of the [[Security Council]] and of the appointment of the [[Secretary-General]].{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-call-strengthening-united-nations|title=The Elders call for strengthening of the United Nations|website=The Elders}} Noting that seventy years since its founding, the UN was still falling short of its Charter pledge "''to save succeeding generations from the scourge of war''", The Elders proposed to: # Make the Security Council more representative of the world today, by introducing a new category of non-permanent members that can be immediately re-elected if they obtained the trust of the other members. As such, they would become de facto permanent members.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/un-fit-purpose|title=A UN fit for purpose|website=The Elders}} # Break the deadlock in the Security Council in situations of atrocity crimes by compelling [[Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council|P-5 member]]'s to pledge that they will not use or threaten to use their veto in case of humanitarian crisis where people are victims of genocide or other atrocities. # Urge the Security Council to make more regular and systematic use of the "[https://www.un.org/en/sc/about/methods/arriaformula.shtml Arria formula]" to give groups representing people in zones of conflict the opportunity to inform and influence Council decisions. # Make the selection process of the Secretary-General more transparent and fair At the [[World Humanitarian Summit]] in May 2016, several Elders featured in a video alongside [[Salil Shetty]], Secretary-General of [[Amnesty International]] and Simon Adams, Executive-Director of the Global Center for the Responsibility to Protect, calling for veto restraint and increased cooperation amongst the [[Permanent members of the United Nations Security Council|Permanent Members of the UN Security Council]] to prevent mass atrocities and save lives.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/ahead-world-humanitarian-summit-elders-urge-un-action-stop-mass-atrocities|title=Ahead of World Humanitarian Summit, The Elders urge UN action to stop mass atrocities|website=The Elders}} In 2016, some of The Elders' recommendations on the selection of the new Secretary-General were adopted by the UN. For the first time, the names of candidates for the position of Secretary-General were publicly circulated, and all declared candidates participated in public hearings in the General Assembly. These changes led to a notable increase in the transparency of the selection process.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-welcome-nomination-antonio-guterres-next-un-secretary-general|title=The Elders welcome nomination of António Guterres as next UN Secretary-General|website=The Elders}} ====Climate Change==== Prior to the 2009 [[United Nations Climate Change conference|United Nations Climate Change Conference]] in Copenhagen, The Elders launched the Climate Change initiative together with their grandchildren.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-enlist-their-grandchildrens-help-climate-change|title=The Elders enlist their grandchildren’s help on climate change|website=The Elders}} The Elders believe that strong leadership is required at all levels in order to deliver a sustainable future. They strongly welcomed the [[Paris Agreement on Climate Change]] reached at the [[COP21]] summit in December 2015, and are working to ensure it is now implemented fully and fairly. The Elders believe that as climate change goes hand in hand with sustainable development, a holistic policy approach that is able to incorporate the voice of civil society and grassroots activities is needed. In this regard, in 2012, The Elders engaged with four young activists in an inter-generational debate on the change needed to secure a sustainable future for the planet, in the run-up to the [[UN Conference on Sustainable Development]] (Rio+20).{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/eldersyoungers-building-sustainable-and-more-equitable-world-all|title=Elders+Youngers: building a sustainable and more equitable world for all|website=The Elders}} Similarly, in 2016, Elders such as Mary Robinson and Gro Harlem Brundtland participated in the Social Good Summit in New York, in which they took part in dialogues with global climate and young activists.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/bad-weather-human-cost-climate-change|title=Bad weather: The Human Cost of Climate Change|website=The Elders}} While The Elders condemned the announcement in June 2017 by President Trump of his intention to withdraw from the Paris Agreement,{{cite web|url=https://www.theelders.org/article/elders-condemn-us-quitting-paris-climate-agreement-no-one-country-can-dismantle-it|title=The Elders condemn US for quitting Paris climate agreement: no one country can dismantle it.|website=The Elders|access-date=2018-02-06}} they note that this has in fact galvanised action by states and cities. They maintain the need to hold governments and businesses to their word so that the deal is implemented in full and in good faith, with adequate means to ratchet up ambition and have reiterated this in subsequent meetings including with Pope Francis and President Macron in late 2017.{{cite web|url=https://www.theelders.org/climate-change|title=Climate change|website=The Elders|access-date=2018-02-06}} ====Equality for Women and Girls==== Commitment to gender equality is a cornerstone of The Elders' engagement in securing dignity and rights for all. From Universal Health Coverage to climate change and mass migration, to peacebuilding and protecting human rights defenders, The Elders believe that women and girls have specific needs that demand appropriately-tailored policy responses. This includes considering the impact of religion and tradition on women's rights,{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/religious-and-traditional-practices-discriminate-against-women-and-girls|title=Religious and traditional practices discriminate against women and girls|website=The Elders}} addressing the harmful practice of [[child marriage]], supporting efforts to promote women as [[peacemakers]],{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/you-cannot-have-sustainable-peace-without-women|title="You cannot have sustainable peace without women"|website=The Elders}} highlighting the specific burdens and responsibilities women face in societies most threatened by climate change, highlighting the scale of violence against women,{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/violence-against-women-increasing-public-awareness|title=Violence against women – increasing public awareness|website=The Elders}} addressing the effect of impunity in prolonging the occurrence of sexual violence in conflict {{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/jimmy-carter-end-impunity-sexual-violence|title=Jimmy Carter: end impunity for sexual violence|website=The Elders}}—including exploitation by [https://www.un.org/en/peacekeeping/operations/ UN Peacekeeping missions]{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-welcome-un-secretary-generals-commitment-fight-sexual-exploitation|title=The Elders welcome UN Secretary-General’s commitment to fight sexual exploitation|website=The Elders}}—and prioritising the health needs of women in the implementation of Universal Health Coverage.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/why-must-women-children-adolescents-be-uhc-priority|title=Why must women, children & adolescents be a UHC priority?|website=The Elders}} In July 2009 The Elders called for an end to harmful and discriminatory practices that are justified on the grounds of religion and tradition. Fernando Henrique Cardoso said that "the idea that God is behind discrimination is unacceptable"{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree|title=This page has been removed – News|work=The Guardian}} Jimmy Carter stated that the Elders call upon "all leaders to challenge and change the harmful teachings and practices, no matter how ingrained, which justify discrimination against women. We ask, in particular, that leaders of all religions have the courage to acknowledge and emphasise the positive messages of dignity and equality that all the world's major faiths share".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2010/01/10/opinion/10kristof.html?ref=opinion|title=Opinion – Religion and Women|first=Nicholas|last=Kristof|publisher=}} ''New York Times'' columnist [[Nicholas Kristof]] later wrote that "The Elders are right that religious groups should stand up for a simple ethical principle: any person's human rights should be sacred, and not depend on something as earthly as their genitals."{{cite web|url=https://www.icrw.org/child-marriage-facts-and-figures/|title=Child Marriage Facts and Figures – ICRW – PASSION. PROOF. POWER.|publisher=}} ====Elders+Youngers==== When Nelson Mandela founded The Elders in 2007, he told the group to listen to the marginalised – especially young people. The Elders' work with young people has consisted in meeting many passionate young people on peace, equality and protecting the environment. In 2012, The Elders and four young activists began an inter-generational debate about the change needed to secure a sustainable future, in the run-up to the U [https://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/rio20 N Conference on Sustainable Development] ([[Rio+20]]). Beside collaborating with young climate activists, The Elders have also hold roundtable discussions on African leadership, debated Egypt's revolution with young people in Cairo, discussed the refugee crisis and UN reform with young students at Sciences Po in Paris and, featured guest blogs from youth contributors on their website.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/africa-2010-game-plan-winning-continent|title=Africa 2010: A Game Plan for a Winning Continent|website=The Elders}}{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-egyptian-youth-you-are-future|title=Elders to Egyptian youth: "You are the future"|website=The Elders}}{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/lakhdar-brahimi-discuss-migration-and-security-sciences-po|title=Lakhdar Brahimi to discuss migration and security at Sciences Po|website=The Elders}}{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/martti-ahtisaari-calls-un-reform-sciences-po-event-paris|title=Martti Ahtisaari calls for UN reform at Sciences Po event in Paris|website=The Elders}}{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/news-media/elders-youngers/guest-blog|title=News & Media|website=The Elders}} ====Iran==== The Elders support greater openness and dialogue between Iran and the international community, and encourage Iran to play a stabilising role in the wider Middle East. In their first visit to Iran as a group, The Elders travelled to Tehran in January 2014 to meet privately with the Iranian leadership.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-conclude-fruitful-first-visit-iran|title=The Elders conclude fruitful first visit to Iran|website=The Elders}} Delegation leader Kofi Annan and fellow Elders Martti Ahtisaari, Desmond Tutu and Ernesto Zedillo held a series of productive meetings on the easing of regional tensions; the spread of extremist violence internationally; human rights; and the Syrian crisis. They were encouraged by Iran's new spirit of openness and dialogue with the outside world. In February 2015, The Elders met again with Foreign Minister [[Javad Zarif]], on the margins of the [[Munich Security Conference]], to encourage a successful conclusion of the [[P5+1]] nuclear negotiations and to discuss solutions to regional security issues. In July 2015, The Elders welcomed the agreement reached on Iran's nuclear programme between Iran, the P5+1 countries (US, Russia, China, UK, France and Germany) and the [[EU]].{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-welcome-iranian-nuclear-agreement-boost-middle-east-peace|title=The Elders welcome Iranian nuclear agreement as boost to Middle East peace|website=The Elders}} They believe the agreement represents a historic opportunity to end decades of animosity between Iran and the West, especially the US, and to rebuild relationships on the basis of trust and mutual respect. In 2016, The Elders issued a press release welcoming the lifting of sanctions against Iran as part of the implementation of the P5+1 nuclear deal, the [[Joint Comprehensive Plan of Action]], which they continued to support throughout the year.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-welcome-lifting-sanctions-against-iran|title=The Elders welcome the lifting of sanctions against Iran|website=The Elders}} In January 2017 The Elders issued a statement following the death of former Iranian President Rafsanjani, stating that "Iran has lost one of its most influential leaders and a strong voice for reform and for the improvement of regional relations."{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-statement-death-former-iranian-president-rafsanjani|title=The Elders’ statement on the death of former Iranian President Rafsanjani|website=The Elders}} At the Munich Security Conference in February 2017 Ernesto Zedillo and Lakhdar Brahimi met again with Javad Zarif. They also hosted a panel debate to defend the Iran Nuclear Agreement, joined by [[Turki bin Faisal Al Saud|HRH Prince Turki]] of Saudi Arabia and [[Hamad bin Khalifa Al Thani|HE Sheikh Hamad of Qatar.]]{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/iran-nuclear-agreement-deal-worth-keeping|title=The Iran Nuclear Agreement: A Deal Worth Keeping?|website=The Elders}} ====Israel and Palestine==== The long-running [[Israeli–Palestinian conflict]] has been one of The Elders' top priorities since the group was founded. Given the far-reaching impact of the unresolved conflict and the power imbalance between the parties, The Elders believe the international community has a vital role to play in helping Israelis and Palestinians reach a lasting solution. Particularly, they insist that the peace efforts must be based on the respect for universal human rights and international humanitarian law, as well as that the siege on [[Gaza Strip|Gaza]] must be permanently lifted and that the boundaries between Israel and a viable Palestinian state must be based on the 1967 borders, including a Palestinian capital in East Jerusalem.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/israel-palestine|title=Israel-Palestine|website=The Elders}} In this regard, in August 2009, The Elders visited [[Israel]] and the [[West Bank]] to draw attention to the impact of the long-running conflict on ordinary people, and to support efforts by Israelis and Palestinians to promote peace.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/print-edition/business/richard-branson-without-mideast-resolution-something-ghastly-could-happen-1.282760|title=Richard Branson: Without Mideast Resolution, 'Something Ghastly' Could Happen|first1=Mike|last1=Dagan|first2=Guy|last2=Rolnik|first3=Asher |last3=Schechter|date=27 August 2009|work=Haaretz}} They were joined on the trip by Richard Branson and Jeff Skoll.{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/news/elders-of-peace-israel-must-freeze-west-bank-settlements-1.282718|title=Elders of Peace: Israel Must Freeze West Bank Settlements|date=26 August 2009|work=Haaretz}} The Elders met Israeli President [[Shimon Peres]], Palestinian Prime Minister [[Salam Fayyad]],{{cite web|author=By ETHAN BRONNERAUG. 27, 2009 |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/08/28/world/middleeast/28bilin.html?_r=2 |title=In Village, Palestinians See Model for Their Cause |work=The New York Times |date=2009-08-27 |accessdate=2018-08-18}} and local peace activists involved in non-violent demonstrations. The report of their visit said they hoped it would "spur leaders and ordinary citizens alike to actions that will further peace, human rights and justice for all in the Middle East".{{cite web|url=http://www.maannews.com/Content.aspx?ID=324344|title=Ex-leaders of US, Ireland to visit region|agency=Maan News Agency}} Four Elders, Mary Robinson, Ela Bhatt, Lakhdar Brahimi, and Jimmy Carter, returned to the Middle East in October 2010 to visit [[Egypt]], Gaza, Israel, [[Jordan]], [[Syria]] and the West Bank. The aim was to encourage peace efforts{{cite web|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/us-usa-mideast-carter-idUSTRE69D5PD20101014|title=Ex-President Carter to start Mideast peace tour|first=Reuters|last=Editorial|publisher=}} with an emphasis on the need to reach "a just and secure peace for all" based on [[international law]].{{cite web|url=http://edition.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/meast/10/21/israel.elders.visit/|title='Elders' visit Israel on Mideast peace tour|publisher=CNN}} Throughout the trip, The Elders held discussions on the [[Israeli–Palestinian peace process|peace process]] with political leaders, representatives of human rights organisations, student and youth groups, women's groups, business, civil society and opinion leaders. During the trip, Mary Robinson said that "As Elders, we believe the two-state solution has the potential to deliver peace – but a more energetic and comprehensive approach is needed."{{cite web|url=http://www.haaretz.com/israel-news/carter-in-syria-israel-must-fully-lift-gaza-blockade-1.320044|title=Carter in Syria: Israel Must Fully Lift Gaza Blockade|date=19 October 2010|work=Haaretz}} The Elders also called for an immediate end to the [[Blockade of the Gaza Strip]], describing it as an "illegal collective punishment" and "an impediment to peace." The Elders released a report outlining their conclusions following the visit, which they hoped would "be a helpful contribution to peace efforts."{{cite web|url=http://www.jpost.com/Diplomacy-and-Politics/Elders-meet-Peres-over-stalemate-in-peace-process|title=Elders meet Peres over stalemate in peace process|work=Jerusalem Post}} In October 2012, Gro Harlem Brundtland, Jimmy Carter and Mary Robinson returned to the region, travelling to Israel, the West Bank and Egypt. {{cite web|url=https://www.yahoo.com/news/jimmy-carter-says-mideast-peace-vanishing-155117602.html|title=Jimmy Carter says Mideast peace is 'vanishing'|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/we-are-heading-towards-one-state-outcome|title=‘We are heading towards a one-state outcome’|website=The Elders}} In their discussions with political leaders, civil society, and humanitarian and human rights experts, the Elders sought to "express concern about the future of the [[two-state solution]] and highlight the effect of [[Israeli settlement|settlement]] expansion and other changes in the city of [[Jerusalem]] as a major impediment to peace between Israelis and Palestinians."{{cite web|url=https://www.businesslive.co.za/bd/|title=Business Day|website=www.businesslive.co.za}} In May 2015, Jimmy Carter and Gro Harlem Brundtland visited Israel and Palestine and ended their visit to Israel and Palestine with a call for meaningful steps to stop the humanitarian crisis in Gaza and reconcile the different Palestinian factions. They held talks with President Mahmoud Abbas and senior political figures from both Israel and Palestine, civil society groups and ordinary citizens to hear their perspectives and convey The Elders' commitment to a fair and enduring resolution to the conflict.{{Cite web |url=https://shmuley.com/2016/01/25/whats-richard-bransons-problem-with-israel/ |title=Archived copy |access-date=25 January 2016 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160201011327/https://shmuley.com/2016/01/25/whats-richard-bransons-problem-with-israel/ |archive-date=1 February 2016 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The Elders supported the diplomatic efforts led by the French Government to keep the two-state solution alive through high-level conferences in Paris in June 2016 and in January 2017. They also welcomed the UN Security Council Resolution in December 2016 that called on Israel to immediately halt all settlement activity in the occupied Palestinian territories.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-welcome-paris-mideast-peace-conference-urge-all-p5-states-show-leadership|title=The Elders welcome Paris Mideast peace conference, urge all P5 states to show leadership|website=The Elders}} They fully support the [[Arab Peace Initiative]],{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/qa-arab-peace-initiative|title=Q&A: the Arab Peace Initiative|website=The Elders}} which calls for normal, peaceful and secure relations between Israel and the Arab world, in return for Israeli withdrawal from Palestinian territory occupied since 1967. In 2017 the Elder's condemned Donald Trump's decision to recognise Jerusalem as the capital of Israel stating this, 'greatly harms peace processes.'{{cite web|url=https://theelders.org/article/elders-condemn-us-recognition-jerusalem-israeli-capital-grave-risk-peace|title=The Elders condemn US recognition of Jerusalem as Israeli capital as grave risk to peace|website=The Elders}} ====Myanmar==== A delegation of Elders visited [[Myanmar]] for the first time as a group in September 2013. In their meetings with senior officials in the government, political leaders, religious leaders and civil society groups, Martti Ahtisaari, Gro Harlem Brundtland and Jimmy Carter explored how best they could support peace and inclusive development in the country.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-encourage-all-parties-myanmar-advance-national-reforms-support-peace-accords|title=The Elders encourage all parties in Myanmar to advance national reforms, support peace accords|website=The Elders}}{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/myanmars-grassroots-should-have-role-national-reforms-peace-talks|title=Myanmar’s grassroots should have a role in national reforms, peace talks|website=The Elders}} The Elders returned to Myanmar in March and December 2014. In the first trip, they travelled to Nay Pyi Taw and Myitkyina, Kachin State, in Myanmar and to Mae Sot and Chiang Mai in Thailand and deepened their relations key interlocutors and focused particularly on representatives of the country's ethnic minorities.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-call-immediate-end-conflict-myanmar-and-urge-parties-engage-talks|title=The Elders call for immediate end to conflict in Myanmar and urge parties to engage in talks|website=The Elders}} In the second one, they visited Yangon and Nay Pyi Taw in Myanmar and Chiang Mai in Thailand, and they reaffirmed their efforts to encourage sustained progress in Myanmar's transition process and called for an immediate end to the conflict.{{Cite web |url=http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-cyprus-talks-carter-idUKTRE48P20D20080926 |title=Archived copy |access-date=26 April 2017 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170427095826/http://uk.reuters.com/article/uk-cyprus-talks-carter-idUKTRE48P20D20080926 |archive-date=27 April 2017 |dead-url=yes |df=dmy-all }} The Elders welcomed the elections in Myanmar in November 2015 and the victory of [[Aung San Suu Kyi|Aung San Suu Kyi']]s [[National League for Democracy]] (NLD) in forming a civilian-led government. In August 2016, Aung San Suu Kyi invited Kofi Annan to chair an independent Commission to assess the situation in [[Rakhine State]], including the [[Rohingya people|Rohingya]] community. The Commission published its final report in August 2017 and put forward recommendations to surmount the political, socio-economic and humanitarian challenges that currently face Rakhine State. On publishing the report, Kofi Annan said: ''"Unless concerted action – led by the government and aided by all sectors of the government and society – is taken soon, we risk the return of another cycle of violence and'' radicalisation'', which will further deepen the chronic poverty that afflicts Rakhine State."'' The Elders supported Kofi Annan in this role, which he undertook in his own capacity. At their October 2017 board meeting, The Elders issued a statement{{cite web|url=https://www.theelders.org/article/elders-call-myanmar-allow-return-displaced-rohingya|title=The Elders call on Myanmar to allow return of displaced Rohingya|website=The Elders|access-date=2018-02-06}} expressing their deep dismay and concern at the wave of violence and destruction that swept through Rakhine State from August 2017, displacing hundreds of thousands of Rohingya Muslims. They called on Myanmar's government and military leaders to allow displaced Rohingya in Bangladesh and other countries to return, and for their human rights and safety to be protected.{{cite web|url=https://www.theelders.org/myanmar|title=Myanmar|website=The Elders|access-date=2018-02-06}} ====Zimbabwe==== [[Zimbabwe]] has been a key focus of concern for The Elders since the group was formed in 2007. Once one of Africa's strongest economies, Zimbabwe has suffered sustained political and economic crises over the last two decades and its leaders are failing in their responsibilities to the country's people. In November 2008, three members of the Elders – Jimmy Carter, Graça Machel and Kofi Annan – planned to visit Zimbabwe to draw attention to the country's escalating humanitarian and economic crises.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-cancel-visit-zimbabwe-meetings-continue-south-africa|title=The Elders cancel visit to Zimbabwe: meetings to continue in South Africa|website=The Elders}} A day before their planned travel to [[Harare]], they were informed that they would be refused entry.{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/nov/22/zimbabwe|title=Jimmy Carter and Kofi Annan refused entry visas to Zimabwe|first=Associated|last=Press|date=22 November 2008|website=the Guardian}} Jimmy Carter said it was the first time he had been denied permission [link] to enter any country.{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/11/23/world/africa/23zimbabwe.html|title=Carter Group Barred From Zimbabwe|first=Celia W.|last=Dugger|publisher=}} The three Elders stayed in [[Johannesburg]] and were briefed by Zimbabwean political and business leaders, aid workers, donors, UN agencies and civil society representatives, many of whom travelled from Zimbabwe to see them. The Elders also held meetings with the leaders of South Africa and Botswana.{{cite web|url=https://mg.co.za/article/2008-11-24-elders-zim-crisis-beyond-what-we-could-have-imagined|title=Elders: Zim crisis 'beyond what we could have imagined'|first=Thembela|last=Khamango|publisher=}} At a press conference after their meetings, they said the situation was "worse than they could have imagined" and called for greater regional and global effort to alleviate the suffering of Zimbabweans.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-zimbabwe-failing-its-people|title=The Elders: Zimbabwe is failing its people|website=The Elders}} Graça Machel said that "the state is no longer able to offer basic services. It can no longer feed, educate or care for its citizens. It is failing its people."{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2009/feb/01/zimbabwe-coalition-deal|title=Nelson Mandela's 'elders' welcome Zimbabwe's coalition deal|first=Associated|last=Press|date=1 February 2009|website=the Guardian}} Following the resignation of President Robert Mugabe in November, 2017 The Elders urged all stakeholders in Zimbabwe and the region to work together for a genuine democratic transition. In 2018 and beyond they will continue to stand in solidarity with the people of Zimbabwe, civil society and human rights defenders in holding the country's new leaders to account.{{cite web|url=https://www.theelders.org/zimbabwe|title=Zimbabwe|website=The Elders|access-date=2018-02-06}} ===Past Work=== ====Child Marriage==== The Elders are committed to ending the practice of child marriage.{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-africa-13681053|title=Ethiopian girls fight child marriages|first=Will|last=Ross|date=7 June 2011|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} In June 2011, Desmond Tutu, Gro Brundtland and Mary Robinson visited [[Amhara, Ethiopia]], to learn about child marriage in a region where half of all female children are married before the age of 15.[109] Alongside their fellow Elder Ela Bhatt, Tutu, Brundtland and Robinson also travelled to [[Bihar]], [[India]] in February 2012. Together, they visited Jagriti, a youth-led project aimed at preventing child marriage, and encouraged the state government's efforts to tackle the issue.{{cite web|url=http://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/city/patna/Elders-advice-Stop-child-marriages/articleshow/11801903.cms?referral=PM|title=Elders' advice: Stop child marriages - Times of India|publisher=}}{{cite web|url=http://www.womensviewsonnews.org/2011/09/girls-not-brides-an-end-to-child-marriages/|title=Girls not brides: an end to child marriages - Women's Views on News|website=www.womensviewsonnews.org}} In 2011, The Elders initiated [[Girls Not Brides]]: The Global Partnership to End Child Marriage, which brings together civil society organisations from around the world that work to tackle child marriage.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/girls-not-brides-new-global-partnership-end-child-marriage|title=Girls Not Brides – a new global partnership to end child marriage|website=The Elders}} The global partnership aims to support activists working for change at the grassroots and call on governments and global organisations to make ending child marriage an international priority. Girls Not Brides became a fully independent organization, spun off from The Elders, in 2013. In July 2016, The Elders welcomed action taken by leaders in The [[Gambia]], [[Tanzania]] and [[Uganda]] to end child marriage, as part of the African Union's continent-wide campaign to eradicate the harmful practice.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-welcome-new-moves-africa-end-child-marriage|title=The Elders welcome new moves in Africa to end child marriage|website=The Elders}} ====Côte d'Ivoire==== Following widespread violence after long-awaited presidential elections in November 2010, The Elders committed to support efforts by the Ivorian government and civil society to promote reconciliation and healing in the country. Desmond Tutu, Kofi Annan and Mary Robinson visited [[Ivory Coast]] on 1–2 May 2011 during which, they not only "encouraged reconciliation and healing", but they also emphasised the importance of improving the country's security situation. Beside meeting the President [[Alassane Ouattara]], Prime Minister [[Guillaume Soro]] and former President [[Laurent Gbagbo]],{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-visit-cote-divoire-encourage-healing-and-national-reconciliation|title=The Elders to visit Côte d'Ivoire to encourage healing and national reconciliation|website=The Elders}} they also brought together civil society organisations, including women's groups seeking a role in the peace process, and encouraged them to work together towards national reconciliation.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-encourage-plans-truth-and-reconciliation-process-cote-divoire|title=The Elders encourage plans for truth and reconciliation process in Côte d'Ivoire|website=The Elders}} They also visited a camp for internally displaced people to hear directly from ordinary people affected by the conflict. Kofi Annan returned to Ivory Coast in January 2012 and October 2013 to support the ongoing reconciliation process. During his visit, he noted the progress that had been made and encouraged all Ivorians to participate in "the task of reconciliation and healing." in order to build an inclusive future and prepare for peaceful elections in 2015.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/media-advisory-kofi-annan-visit-cote-divoire-9-10-october-2013|title=Media advisory: Kofi Annan to visit Côte d’Ivoire from 9-10 October 2013|website=The Elders}}{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2011/04/26/world/asia/26korea.html|title=Carter and Other Former Leaders to Travel to North Korea|first=Mark|last=McDonald|publisher=}} ====Cyprus==== The Elders began working on [[Cyprus]] in September 2008, when the leaders of the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot communities formally entered into peace negotiations. Since then, they have visited the island four times to support all efforts to build peace, enhance trust, and sharing their experiences with leaders and civil society in order to encourage dialogue.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/cyprus |title=Cyprus |publisher=The Elders |date= |accessdate=2018-08-18}} Additionally, they worked with the [http://www.cmp-cyprus.org/ Committee on Missing Persons] in Cyprus and the [http://cyprusfriendship.org/ Cyprus Friendship Programme] to film the documentary "[https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RGh_rbPLfV4&list=UUWJWr0Cs6UVNEyquN9dEItA Digging the Past in Search of the Future]" with the hope that this could help Cypriots to reach a common understanding about their shared past.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/cyprus-digging-past-search-future|title=Cyprus: Digging the Past in Search of the Future|website=The Elders}} In October 2008, the Elders visited the island to support the newly begun peace talks between the Greek Cypriot and Turkish Cypriot leaders. Desmond Tutu said that "These opportunities don't come around very often".{{cite web|url=http://www.cyprusedirectory.com/articleview.aspx?ID=4375|title=Elders arrive to lend their moral support - Cyprus Internet Directory|publisher=}} Elders Jimmy Carter, Lakhdar Brahimi and Desmond Tutu met political leaders, civil society representatives and young people from both communities.{{cite web|url=https://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2008-10-08-1893099243_x.htm|title=World peacemakers offer support for Cyprus talks - USATODAY.com|website=usatoday30.usatoday.com}} Throughout the visit they made it clear that they were visiting the island to offer support and not to get formally involvement in the peace process. Gro Harlem Brundtland and Lakhdar Brahimi visited Athens, Ankara and Cyprus in September 2009 to encourage efforts to reunify the island. In Ankara they met Turkish President [[Abdullah Gül]],{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/cyprus-peace-process-going-well-facing-challenges|title=Cyprus peace process going well, but facing challenges|website=The Elders}} and President [[George Papandreou]] in Athens. In [[Nicosia]] they met Turkish Cypriot leader [[Mehmet Ali Talat]] and Greek Cypriot leader [[Dimitris Christofias]].{{cite web|url=http://www.cyprusedirectory.com/articleview.aspx?ID=14527|title=The Elders in Cyprus to help peace process - Cyprus Internet Directory|publisher=}} The Elders also met local media and leading women from politics, business and civil society on the island.{{cite web|url=http://www.cyprusedirectory.com/cyprusguide/cyprus.aspx?ID=14551|title=Elders: Cypriot media ‘scathing and pessimistic’ - Cyprus Guide|publisher=}} In December 2009, Desmond Tutu, Jimmy Carter and Lakhdar Brahimi returned to Cyprus. They convened a public meeting on how trust could be engendered between conflicting communities and together with the Committee on Missing Persons filmed the documentary, "[http://www.theelders.org/article/cyprus-digging-past-search-future Cyprus: Digging the Past in Search of the Future]". Such documentary follows the three Elders as they accompany four young Cypriots to learn about the search for the remains of thousands of missing people who were killed in the violence of the 1960s and 1970s.{{cite web|url=http://www.hri.org/news/cyprus/cna/2011/11-02-08_1.cna.html|title=Cyprus News Agency: News in English, 11-02-08|website=www.hri.org}} It was launched in early 2011 with special screenings in Nicosia and at the Houses of Parliament in London.. In Cyprus, Desmond Tutu and Gro Brundtland also met the newly elected leader of the Turkish Cypriot community, [[Derviş Eroğlu]] and the leader of the Greek Cypriot community, [[Demetris Christofias]], and called for a renewed spirit of leadership in Cyprus. The Elders also met the Archbishop of the Church of Cyprus, Chrysostomos II, to discuss the role of religious leaders in peacebuilding. ====Korean Peninsula==== The Elders launched their [[Korean Peninsula]] initiative in April 2011, when a delegation led by Jimmy Carter made a six-day visit to the [[Republic of Korea]] (South Korea), the [[Democratic People's Republic of Korea]] (North Korea) and [[China]].{{cite web|url=http://www.aljazeera.com/news/asia-pacific/2011/04/201142634658654793.html|title=Carter leads North Korea peace mission|website=www.aljazeera.com}} Jimmy Carter, together with Martti Ahtisaari, Gro Harlem Brundtland and Mary Robinson, aimed to alleviate tensions on the Peninsula, particularly by encouraging dialogue and addressing security and humanitarian concerns such as reported food shortages in North Korea.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/qa-elders-visit-korean-peninsula|title=Q&A: The Elders' visit to the Korean Peninsula|website=The Elders}} In all three countries they met senior government officials, diplomats, UN representatives, humanitarian agencies, researchers, think tanks and North Korean refugees who fled to South Korea. Throughout the visit they made it clear that they were acting independently and did not intend "to replace or intervene in any official process".{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/report-elders-visit-korean-peninsula-and-china-april-2011|title=Report: The Elders’ visit to the Korean Peninsula and China, April 2011|website=The Elders}} In a report released following the Elders' visit, Jimmy Carter stated: "''On relations between North and South Korea, there are no quick fixes…and progress will require greater flexibility, sincerity and commitment from all parties''".{{cite web|url=https://www.koreatimes.co.kr/www/news/nation/2011/07/113_91703.html|title=The Elders hail talks with N. Korea|date=27 July 2011|publisher=}} Martti Ahtisaari and Gro Harlem Brundtland later travelled to Brussels to brief senior European Union officials on their findings. ====Sudan and South Sudan==== Peace in Sudan became a top priority for The Elders as soon as the group was founded. Indeed, The Elders' first mission was to [[Sudan]], from 30 September to 4 October 2007. Desmond Tutu, Lakhdar Brahimi, Jimmy Carter and Graça Machel travelled to the country to learn more about the humanitarian situation in [[Darfur]] and to affirm the group's support for the [[Comprehensive Peace Agreement]] (CPA), which was negotiated between North and South Sudan in 2005 to end its 22-year [[civil war]]. The Elders published a report on their findings titled 'Bringing Hope, Forging Peace: The Elders' Mission to Sudan'.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/sudan-south-sudan|title=Sudan & South Sudan|website=The Elders}} In 2008, the Elders encouraged states to provide urgently needed helicopters for peacekeepers in Darfur.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/humanitarian-situation-will-deteriorate-sharply-sudan-after-expulsion-aid-workers|title=Humanitarian situation will deteriorate sharply in Sudan after expulsion of aid workers|website=The Elders}} In March 2009 the Elders called for aid agencies to be given access to Sudan following their expulsion by the Sudanese government.{{cite web|url=https://www.huffingtonpost.com/desmond-tutu/sudan-between-peril-and-h_b_423300.html|title=Sudan Between Peril and Hope|first1=Desmond|last1=Tutu|first2=Lakhdar|last2=Brahimi|date=18 March 2010|publisher=}} Ahead of [[South Sudan]]'s self-determination referendum in January 2011, The Elders warned of a risk of renewed violence in Sudan and urged 'swift and bold action' by the international community in support of the peace process.{{cite web|url=https://www.cartercenter.org/news/pr/sudan-010311.html|title=Jimmy Carter, Kofi Annan, Joseph Warioba, and John Hardman to Lead Carter Center Delegation to Observe Referendum on Self-Determination of Southern Sudan|website=www.cartercenter.org}} Particularly, Jimmy Carter and Kofi Annan led the Carter Center delegation to observe the [[South Sudanese independence referendum, 2011|referendum on self-determination in South Sudan.]]{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-sudan-and-south-sudan-initiative-2012|title=The Elders’ Sudan and South Sudan initiative, 2012|website=The Elders}} In 2012, prompted by the "worsening relations between Sudan and South Sudan, deteriorating economic conditions in both countries, and renewed conflict in the Sudanese states of [[Blue Nile]] and [[South Kordofan]]", The Elders decided to make a series of visits to Sudan, South Sudan and Ethiopia.{{cite web|url=http://www.sudantribune.com/Sudan-is-willing-to-withdraw-its,42725|title=Sudan is willing to withdraw its troops from Abyei, President Carter - Sudan Tribune: Plural news and views on Sudan|website=www.sudantribune.com}} They aimed to highlight the growing humanitarian crisis and encourage further peace talks between the governments of Sudan and South Sudan. In May 2012, Lakhdar Brahimi and Jimmy Carter met Sudanese President [[Omar al-Bashir]] in Khartoum.{{cite web|url=http://www.unhcr.org/4ffb07349.html|title=The Elders visit Sudanese refugees on peace errand|first=United Nations High Commissioner for|last=Refugees|publisher=}} In July 2012, Martti Ahtisaari, Mary Robinson and Desmond Tutu travelled to South Sudan to meet President [[Salva Kiir]] and civil society representatives, and to visit Yusuf Batil refugee camp near the border with Sudan.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-congratulate-south-sudan-first-anniversary-independence|title=The Elders congratulate South Sudan on first anniversary of independence|website=The Elders}} They also travelled to Ethiopia, where they met [[Hailemariam Desalegn]] and members of the [[African Union]] High-Level Implementation Panel on Sudan (AUHIP), including [[Thabo Mbeki]] and [[Pierre Buyoya]]. At the conclusion of their visit, Ahtisaari, Tutu and Robinson urged presidents Bashir and Kiir to meet as soon as possible and recommit to peace. Desmond Tutu stated: "''Peace, peace, peace is what the people of Sudan and South Sudan need most. Recent months have seen increased hardship and suffering in both countries. It is a fragile time and I hope that the leaders will do what their people need, which is to recommit to working together to build two viable states.''"{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/world/2008/nov/15/zimbabwe-united-nations-kofi-annan|title=Annan to lead team on humanitarian mission to Harare|first=Xan|last=Rice|date=15 November 2008|website=the Guardian}} ====Sri Lanka==== The Elders have closely followed developments in [[Sri Lanka]] and spoken out on several occasions since the end of the decades-long conflict in 2009. Particularly, The Elders have persistently emphasised the importance of achieving reconciliation and accountability for violations committed during the conflict. In November 2009, the Elders wrote to Sri Lankan [[President Rajapaksa]]{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-call-sri-lankan-government-protect-rights-civilians-displaced-conflict|title=The Elders call on Sri Lankan government to protect rights of civilians displaced by conflict|website=The Elders}} as well as major donors, calling on the government to protect the rights of displaced civilians following years of war. Desmond Tutu said the government had "an obligation to serve all Sri Lanka's citizens – including the Tamil and other minority communities".{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-south-asia-10851163|title=Elders group criticises Sri Lanka|first=Saroj|last=Pathirana|date=3 August 2010|publisher=|via=www.bbc.co.uk}} In August 2010, The Elders expressed disappointment at the Sri Lankan government's clampdown on domestic critics and "disdain for human rights". The Elders added that meaningful progress on reconciliation on the island was still "desperately needed".{{cite web|url=http://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2012/feb/26/our-duty-sri-lanka-human-rights|title=Our duty to Sri Lanka, and human rights - Desmond Tutu and Mary Robinson|first1=Desmond|last1=Tutu|first2=Mary|last2=Robinson|date=26 February 2012|website=the Guardian}} In February 2012, Mary Robinson and Desmond Tutu wrote an op-ed in [[The Guardian]], urging the member states of the [[United Nations Human Rights Council]] "to support a resolution that seeks accountability for the terrible violations of international law that have taken place, and establishes mechanisms to monitor progress on the steps the government is taking on accountability".{{cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2012/03/23/world/asia/rights-body-passes-measure-on-sri-lanka.html|title=U.N. Rights Council Passes Sri Lanka Resolution|first=Nick|last=Cumming-Bruce|publisher=}} The U.S.-backed resolution on 'Promoting reconciliation and accountability in Sri Lanka' was adopted by the Council on 22 March 2012.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/sri-lanka-needs-know-world-watching|title=Sri Lanka needs to know the world is watching|website=The Elders}} Robinson and Tutu wrote a further op-ed published in [[The Times]], [[The Times of India]] and the [[Tribune de Genève]] in March 2013, calling on the Council and the Commonwealth to exert pressure on Sri Lanka's government to implement the recommendations of the [[Lessons Learnt and Reconciliation Commission]] (LLRC).{{cite web|url=http://reliefweb.int/report/sudan/bringing-hope-forging-peace-elders-mission-sudan|title=Bringing hope, forging peace - The Elders' mission to Sudan|publisher=}} ===Other Activities=== The organisation has also issued statements on a range of topics including those relating to [[Tibet]],{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/pakistan-floods-elders-urge-world-respond-more-quickly-and-generously|title=PAKISTAN FLOODS: The Elders urge the world to respond more quickly and generously|website=The Elders}} [[Pakistan]],{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-condemn-deadly-attacks-norway|title=The Elders condemn deadly attacks in Norway|website=The Elders}} [[Norway]],{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/ela-bhatt-urges-partnership-poor-opening-un-meeting-mdgs|title=Ela Bhatt urges ‘partnership with the poor’ at opening of UN meeting on MDGs|website=The Elders}} the [[International Criminal Court]],{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-urge-all-states-commit-universal-impartial-international-criminal-court|title=The Elders urge all states to commit to universal, impartial International Criminal Court|website=The Elders}} and the [[Millennium Development Goals]].{{cite web|url=http://russia-insider.com/en/politics/world-influencers-elders-meet-moscow/6306|title=World Influencers "The Elders" Meet in Moscow|date=1 May 2015|publisher=}} ====Kenya==== Widespread violence erupted in [[Kenya]] in December 2007, following disputes over the results of national elections. In January 2008, the African Union established a Panel of Eminent African Personalities to mediate a solution to the crisis, headed by Kofi Annan and including Graça Machel and former Tanzanian Prime Minister [[Benjamin Mkapa]]. Earlier, the Kenyan churches had launched an unsuccessful mediation attempt headed by South African Archbishop and Elders chair, Desmond Tutu. While three Elders were involved in efforts to resolve Kenya's crisis, this was not an initiative of The Elders.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-peaceful-solutions-must-be-sought-kenya|title=The Elders: Peaceful solutions must be sought in Kenya|website=The Elders}} The Elders issued a brief statement in January 2008 calling for an end to the violence. ====Middle East and North Africa==== Following [[Arab Spring|major demonstrations across the Middle East and North Africa]] in 2011, The Elders stated that they stood in solidarity with "all those crying out for freedom and basic rights". In an interview with CNN, Desmond Tutu called on the international community to bring pressure to bear on [[Muammar Gaddafi]] to relinquish power.{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/elders-begin-two-day-visit-egypt|title=The Elders begin two-day visit to Egypt|website=The Elders}} In November 2011, a few weeks after elections to Tunisia's Constituent Assembly, Martti Ahtisaari, Mary Robinson and Lakhdar Brahimi travelled to Tunis to attend the annual gathering of the [[Mo Ibrahim Foundation]]. In an interview with the BBC following her meeting with Tunisian bloggers, Mary Robinson described the "sense of buoyant democracy" in the country. Gro Harlem Brundtland, Jimmy Carter and Mary Robinson travelled to [[Cairo]] in October 2012. During their meetings with President [[Mohamed Morsi]], senior officials and diplomats, representatives of civil society organisations and young people, the Elders emphasised the importance of "an inclusive, democratic transition."{{cite web|url=http://www.theelders.org/article/egypt-transition-elders-visit-cairo|title=Egypt in transition: Elders visit Cairo|website=The Elders}}{{cite web|url=https://www.cartercenter.org/news/trip_reports/egypt-011712.html|title=Trip Report by Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter to Egypt, Jan. 8-14, 2012|website=www.cartercenter.org}} Brundtland and Carter both visited [[Egypt]] earlier in 2012, where they met civil society organisations and spoke to students at the [[American University in Cairo]]. Carter also travelled to Egypt with [[The Carter Center]] to witness the country's [[Egyptian presidential election, 2012|presidential]] and parliamentary elections in January{{cite web|url=https://www.cartercenter.org/news/trip_reports/egypt-0529.html|title=Trip Report by Former U.S. President Jimmy Carter to Egypt, May 21-28, 2012|website=www.cartercenter.org}} and May 2012. Outside of their role as Elders, Kofi Annan and Lakhdar Brahimi have individually been involved in the international efforts to try to resolve the conflict in [[Syria]]. In February 2012, Annan was appointed Joint Special Envoy of the United Nations and [[League of Arab States]] on the [[Syrian Civil War]].{{cite web|url=https://www.un.org/apps/news/story.asp?NewsID=42702#.WQDDGFPyvJO|title=UN, Arab League appoint veteran diplomat to take over Annan’s role on Syrian crisis|date=17 August 2012|publisher=}} He was succeeded in the role by Brahimi, who was appointed Joint Special Representative in August 2012, a position he held until May 2014. ====Russia==== The Elders held a three-day visit to [[Moscow]] in April 2015. Kofi Annan, Gro Harlem Brundtland, Martti Ahtisaari, Lakhdar Brahimi, Jimmy Carter and Ernesto Zedillo held talks on geopolitical issues with Russian officials, including [[President Putin]], Foreign Minister [[Lavrov]] and former Soviet President [[Mikhail Gorbachev]].{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-conclude-three-day-visit-moscow|title=The Elders conclude three-day visit to Moscow|website=The Elders}} ===Campaigns=== ====#WalkTogether==== Together with civil society partners, The Elders marked their 10th anniversary by launching [https://www.walk-together.org/ #WalkTogether], a year-long global campaign to inspire hope and bridge the deepening global fault lines of division, hate and xenophobia. The campaign is intended to celebrate those communities whose work is a great demonstration of empathy, where their actions benefit 'the many', create a sense of unity, and address global and local challenges in a compassionate way. In other words, #WalkTogether aims to lift the voices of courageous moral leadership in communities around the world, who are working for the freedoms aligned to those to which Nelson Mandela dedicated his life. These [https://www.walk-together.org/freedoms/ Freedoms] include the broad themes of Peace, Health, Justice and Equality. The campaign ran for twelve months from 18 July 2017 – the tenth anniversary of the group's founding – to 18 July 2018, the centenary of Nelson Mandela's birth.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/walk-together|title=Walk Together|website=The Elders}} ====Every Human Has Rights==== The Every Human Has Rights (EHHR) campaign was launched on the 60th anniversary of the [[Universal Declaration of Human Rights]] (UDHR), 10 December 2007, in [[Cape Town]], [[South Africa]]. The Elders launched the initiative in partnership with a diverse group of global NGOs, civil society organisations and businesses to highlight UDHR principles, including the right to health, women's rights, and freedom of expression. Launch partners included ActionAid, [[Amnesty International]], the Center for Women's Global Leadership, [[International PEN]], [https://witness.org/ WITNESS], [http://www.who.int/workforcealliance/members_partners/member_list/realizingrights/en/ Realizing Rights], [[Save the Children]] and [[UNICEF]]. The EHHR campaign also included partners from civil society organisations in the developing world through networks like [[CIVICUS]]. The campaign aimed to "empower global citizens to protect and realize the first-ever comprehensive agreement on [[human rights]] among nations". Throughout the campaign, over one billion people signed the Universal Declaration, taking responsibility and pledging to speak to protect the freedom and the rights of others in their communities.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/elders-launch-every-human-has-rights-campaign|title=The Elders launch the Every Human Has Rights campaign|website=The Elders}} A year later, in December 2008, The Elders joined award-winning human rights journalists, leaders in civil society, and business and government leaders to celebrate the Every Human Has Rights campaign and participate in the EHHR Media Awards.{{cite web|url=http://theelders.org/article/every-human-has-rights-media-awards|title=Every Human Has Rights Media Awards|website=The Elders}} ==References== {{3rd party|date=August 2018}} {{Reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.theelders.org/ The Elders' official website] {{The Elders|state=expanded}} {{Nelson Mandela}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Elders (Organization), The}} [[Category:Peace organizations]] [[Category:International human rights organizations]] [[Category:Organizations established in 2007]] [[Category:Nelson Mandela]] [[Category:Jimmy Carter]] [[Category:Peter Gabriel]] [[Category:Kofi Annan]]
